attributes.title: Group survival and the perceived importance of political diversity

q1.value: Group survival and the perceived importance of political diversity (minority rights threat) - Revised materials

q2.value: Uri Lifshin, Gilad Hirschberger, Michal Reifen Tagar, Tali Aloni

q3.value:
The purpose of this research was to test the hypothesis that beyond peoples' personal political views, they realize the importance of heterogeneity in political views as a means of promoting group survival.

In the earlier experiments people with different political views did in fact prefer political diversity/ heterogeneity in their group.
Under conditions of threat of war participants preferred a relatively larger percent of right-wing individuals compared to conditions that implied that there is an opportunity for peace – beyond their personal political beliefs.

We then conducted another study to test if people would prefer more left wingers to deal with other topics, such as threats to minorities, promotion of tolerance in society. We indeed found support for that. 

The goal of the current study was to test if making the issue of the importance of tolerance towards others in society salient would cause people to prefer that there would be more left wingers in society and in the government, compared to a control condition in which issues with public transportation in Israel will be salient 

In the current study participants will be randomly assigned to complete a short manipulation where they are asked to think about either what needs to be done to increase tolerance towards others or about what needs to be done to improve national security in their country. Another group will get none of these questions. 

After this brief manipulation participants will answer a set of question regarding the topic (how important it is to them) followed by questions about what percentage of people in the political left and right would be optimal for Israel. They will also write what they think is positive about both political parties. We will also add a variable asking for their explicit support for political heterogeneity in their country.

Personal political view will be measured at the end of the study and will be used as a covarite. 

Participants will then be debriefed about the purpose of the study.

q4.value:
Our hypothesis is that while participants who read that participants who would think about the need for more Tolerance in their country would prefer more left-wing people in the public and government – regardless of the own participant’s political views.  
Participants who would think about needs for national security would prefer more right wingers compared to the other conditions. 

We will probe for interactions with political view, but generally expect a main effect beyond political view (using political view as a covariate).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
Personnel who analyze the data collected from the study are not aware of the treatment applied to any given group.

question.value: 3 groups. We will also test for interactions with political view -- either as a continuous variable, and also when its categorized into left wing, right wing and center. Again our hypotheses is of a main effect

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to conditions using Qualtirics' auto randomization function.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
We will conduct a study online on Reddit (on Rsample size as well as non-partisan political subreddits and subreddits of countries that will also positing the study) . Here we will ask participants to state what country they are from. 
Participants who report not completing the study in 1 time or having difficulties will be excluded. 
Participants who will not write anything related to the question in the open ended manipulation will be removed
Participants with missing data on critical variables will be excluded. 
Participant who reported not completing the study seriously (over 5 on a 9 point scale will be excluded
Participants who take  too little time to complete the study (the study is short so we will have to see what the average time is, but generally it should take more than 30 seconds online minute. 
duplicate IP addresses  will be removed 

For the within country analysis, we will remove participants who reported currently living in a different country from their home country.

q13.value:
We will try to collect data from 250 participants 

In the reddit sample we are limited to how many times we can post the study in many subreddits (aside from rsamplesize) so we will have to see if the study gets attention or not. We will aim for a total sample of at least 250 participants. But if we can we will try to get more.

q14.value: Power analysis (a-priori, F family) indicated that to find a medium-small effect (partial eta squared of ,04) effect at 80% power with 3 groups in an ANCOVA we will 235 participants.

q15.value:
In the Reddit sample we may want to collect data from as many people as we can, since they may be of different nationalities, and this can increase the chance that we get close to the needed sample size in various countries. Again we can use a basic international sample - as our previous studies showed relative generalization of the effects,  but if we can we would want to have a bigger sample. 
On the other had we can get 0 or very few responses from various countries - in case that our post would not get attention.

question.value:
Participants will be randomly assigned to think about what needs to be done to improve either - Tolerance towards others
- National security
- no question (control)

We have 1 dependent variable (1-item) pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in the public and  1 dependent variable (1-item)  pertaining to preferences for right/left wingers in  government in their country.

We also have a few questions about the importance of the topic. These are meant to  Specifically the item that measure how important the topic is to the participant personally and to Israel in general.  We will also check if these are correlated to preference of right / left wingers within each condition (it should be correlated more with left wingers in the Tolerance condition, but more with right wingers in the Security condition). 

We will also include an open ended question about the positive things about left/ right wingers  (these will be coded for themes). We expect that more mentioning of left wingers' care for minority rights and tolerance (we are expecting this to be a theme) would be mentioned - and we will also test if these mentions were grater in tolerance condition.

To examine our hypothesis reg the 2 items measuring preferences for political diversity we will first run a MANCOVA anlysis (to reduce the chance for type 1 error), and then also look at the univariate level for each of the 2 items.

As mentioned, we will run a MANCOVA (controlling for political view). But first we will also prob for interactions (looking at political view both as a continuous variable and as a categorized variable of 3 levels). If the interaction is sig, we will report that analysis rather than the MANCOVA/ANCOVA. If its not then political view would only be used as a covariate. We will also examine if religiosity is a sig covariate or not. 

NOTE THAT IN THE REDDIT STUDY WE WILL NOT CENTER THE POLITICAL ATTITUDE VARIABLE BUT RATHER USED EXPLICIT CATEGORIES TO PREVENT MISREPRESENTATION OF THE POLITICAL VIEW.

q20.value: We have a coding scheme for the categorical variables based on previous research.

q21.value: Sig effects are at 95% confidence (p < .05). We have a directional hypothesis so for us p < 05 on a 1 tailed test would be considered statistically significant (or marginally statistically significant)

q22.value:
In the Israeli field study Participants who wont complete the materials properly (i.e., alone, in the right order, not being on the phone etc) will be excluded. 
Non-Jews will be excluded (since this affects political views in Israel). 
Participants who will not write anything related to the question in the open ended manipulation will be removed
Participants with missing data on critical variables will be excluded. 

In the Reddit Study 
Participants who report not completing the study in 1 time or having difficulties will be excluded. 
Participants who will not write anything related to the question in the open ended manipulation will be removed
Participants with missing data on critical variables will be excluded. 
Participant who reported not completing the study seriously (over 5 on a 9 point scale will be excluded
Participants who take  too little time to complete the study (the study is short so we will have to see what the average time is, but generally it should take more than 30 - 1 minute seconds online 
duplicate IP addresses  will be removed 

For the within country analysis, we will remove participants who reported currently living in a different country from their home country.

q23.value:
If participants have missing data on critical variables (the attention check, the main DV, or their political view) they will be excluded from the analysis. 

Exploratory analysis

q24.value:
We will test if the degree to which participants think that the topic is important relates to the results (we do predict that the more they would  care about it the more they will want more left wingers to be in society). 

We may also run exploratory analyses with participant's open ended responses.

attributes.title: Reconsidering the Automaticity of Visual Statistical Learning
attributes.description:
This OSF pre-registration was originally created for "Experiment 1" (in the attached manuscript).  
Now a repository for all materials regarding the resulting manuscript.

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Follow-up conditions from "Reconsidering the Automaticity of Visual Statistical Learning" (Himberger et al., PsyArXiv 2019)

other.value: We will measure how forced-choice performance and triplet creation performance vary with participants’ awareness of regularities in the stimulus stream from the initial exposure phase.

sample.value: Each of the four conditions above will include 120 subjects. Within each condition, each participant will be assigned to a unique stimulus set (for counterbalancing), and the same group of 120 stimulus sets will be used in all four conditions. These stimulus sets will be identical to those employed in Himberger et al. (2019). Any subjects collected in a repeated stimulus set (because of online data over-collection), will be held out and excluded from the main analyses.

outliers.value: Exclusions are identical to those listed in Himberger et al., 2019 (PsyArXiv)

dependent.value: Primary DVs are identical to Himberger et al., 2019 (PsyArXiv): response time facilitation between triplet position 1 and triplet position 3, proportion of 2AFC trials correct, and number of triplets created relative to "foil" triplets created. Additionally, we will assess participants’ knowledge of regularities in the stimulus stream via a series of post-exposure questions. These questions will be presented in a “funnel” style, starting with general questions about regularities, and progressing to more specific questions about what participants may have noticed in the stream.

conditions.value:
We will employ a full between-subjects design. There will be four conditions. Each condition will be a close variant of the existing paradigm described in Himberger et al., 2019 (PsyArXiv). 

The four variants are: 
(1) No TD:  To Remove the Target Detection Task 
(2) Attend Stimuli: Replace the cover task (i.e. Jiggle Task) with instructions to attend to the stimuli 
(3) Attend Relations: Replace the cover task (i.e. Jiggle Task) with instructions to attend to the relationships between the stimuli 
(4) Attend Triplets: Replace  the cover task (i.e. Jiggle Task) with instructions to attend to the triplet structure, and instructions that there are four unique image triplets.

hypothesis.value: We hypothesize that performance on visual statistical learning tasks will be improved under conditions which encourage participants to attend to the sequential structure of an image stream. In particular, between four conditions, we expect to observe the lowest force-choice recognition performance when participants perform a motion detection cover task during visual exposure without additional exposure to sequential structure in a target detection task ("no TD"). Performance will be relatively increased when participants are instructed to simply attend to the stimuli (“Attend Stimuli”).  Similarly, performance will again be relatively increased when they are instructed to attend to relationships between the images (“Attend Relations”). Finally, the greatest forced-choice accuracy will be observed when participants are instructed beforehand to attend to the “triplet” structure of the stimuli (i.e. that images occur in sets of three) and that there are four unique “triplets” that recur in the image stream (“Attend Triplets”).

attributes.title: Beyond GPA: SES, Mindsets and Subjective Academic Outcomes During College

q1.value: Beyond GPA: How SES And Mindsets Predict Subjective Academic Outcomes in College

q3.value: This study draws from the ongoing longitudinal study, the Identity Pathways Project.  While much of Carol Dweck's mindsets literature has focused on how mindsets predict objective indicators of performance, such as GPA, there are several other important academic outcomes that are more subjective, such as academic adjustment and academic identity development, that have been shown to be critical for optimal student success and development, especially during college. Additionally, there has been increasing attention to the impact of socioeconomic status on college student adjustment and identity development. In this project, we seek to examine how mindsets predict academic adjustment  and academic identity over time in the first two years of college, along with whether SES relates to mindsets and whether SES moderates the relationship between mindsets and academic adjustment and academic identity. We take a narrative approach to identity, focusing on how students make meaning from academic high points and low points narrated at the end of the first and second year of college.  It should be noted here that this project is part of a longitudinal study that was started in 2013 and includes two different cohorts of students from two different campuses, with a staggered start to data collection spanning three years (2013-2015). Thus, we did some initial analyses on a fourth of the current sample (first cohort, first campus) that are relevant to the current project and were presented in SPSP posters in 2016 and 2017.  One poster showed that lower SES students reported lower academic adjustment during the first year of college, and the other poster showed that an increase in the growth mindset from the first to the second year of college was predicted by exploratory processing in academic high points, even after controlling for academic satisfaction and GPA. These sets of analyses used variables that will be related to each other in the current analyses.

q4.value:
1) We will test the relationship between mindset and SES.  Past research is mixed, so this is exploratory. However, some research does suggest that lower SES will be associated with more of a fixed mindset about academic ability.
2) We hypothesize that the fixed mindset measured at the beginning of college will predict more negative academic outcomes and an increase in negative outcomes over time during the first and second year of college.  Specifically we hypothesize that a) the fixed mindset will predict more negative meaning-making about the self in academic high point and low point narratives both at the end of the first and second year of college, and b) the fixed mindset will predict lower academic adjustment and a decreasing pattern from first to second year.  We will examine all of this with and without controlling for academic GPA.
3) We hypothesize that the patterns predicted in hypothesis #2 will be moderated by SES such that the relations between fixed mindset and negative outcomes will be stronger for those lower in SES, as measured by family household income and parental educational attainment (composite).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: As mentioned above data are drawn from the Identity Pathways Project, which is documented on this OSF page.  The overall design is provided there.  There are three surveys a year each for four years of college, and the surveys include many quantitative scales and narrative prompts.  For the current analyses, mindset was measured at Wave 1 (summer before college) and Wave 4 (beginning of sophomore year), SES indicators were measured at Wave 1, academic high point and low point narratives were provided at Waves 3 (end of first year) and Wave 6 (end of sophomore year) and the academic adjustment measure was provided at Wave 2 (middle of first year) and Wave 5 (middle of sophomore year).  Finally, GPA was assessed at Wave 4 (beginning of sophomore year).

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: As noted above, this project uses data from a longitudinal study that has been ongoing since 2013, and some of the variables have been examined in relation to one another on sub-sets of the sample.  The supervising faculty author was involved in the earlier preliminary analyses, but  the students who developed the current hypotheses were not.

question.value: See general materials for IPP for the data collection procedures for the longitudinal study.  For this specific set of analyses, we used a specific set of inclusion criteria regarding who from the longitudinal study would be included.  Our inclusion criteria was that we would include all those participants who a) completed Wave 1 (mindset  and SES) and Wave 4 (GPA), and b) completed at least one wave including one of the subjective academic outcome indicators, which would mean completing either Wave 2 (academic adjustment), Wave 3 (academic high points and low points for first year), Wave 5 (academic adjustment) or Wave 6 (academic high points and low points for sophomore year).

q13.value: See description of IPP in the main study.  600 participants were initially recruited across two cohorts and two colleges. With attrition, the longitudinal sample used in the currently sample (inclusion criteria provided above) across the first two years of data collected for this set of analyses is approximately 400.

q14.value: Sample size predetermined by constraints on the longitudinal study.

q15.value: not relevant -- data already fully collected.

question.value: No manipulated variables.

See above, the variables are mindset (fixed vs. growth mindset for ability) at two time points -- Wave 1 and Wave 4; academic adjustment scale at Waves 2 and 5, positive and negative self-event connections and exploratory processing coded from academic high point and low point narratives at Waves 3 and 6; indicators of SES at Wave 1, and GPA at Wave 4.
For SES, we are using a composite of household income, father's educational attainment, and mother's educational attainment.  These three variables will be z-scored and averaged together.

Correlational and regression analyses will be used.  All bivariate correlations among study variables will be run. Specifically,  mindset scales will be correlated with SES indicators and indicators of academic adjustment, academic narrative identity, and GPA.  Additionally, multiple regression analysis will be used to examine how mindset predicts change in academic indicators over time, with and without controlling for GPA.  Finally, moderated multiple regression will be used to test whether SES moderates relations between mindset and academic outcomes.

q20.value: Narrative variables are coded using coding systems available on the main IPP page for exploratory processing and self-event connections.

q21.value: We will use traditional p < .05 significance testing for our analyses.

q24.value: We have specific hypotheses and corresponding regression analyses spelled out above, but we simply plan to look at the bivariate correlations among all of main study variables in order to understand what is going on. This is a hugely labor intensive  long-term longitudinal study, and it makes sense to explore the data to build on it for future research.

registration_responses.q5: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11: As noted above, this project uses data from a longitudinal study that has been ongoing since 2013, and some of the variables have been examined in relation to one another on sub-sets of the sample.  The supervising faculty author was involved in the earlier preliminary analyses, but  the students who developed the current hypotheses were not.
registration_responses.q13: See description of IPP in the main study.  600 participants were initially recruited across two cohorts and two colleges. With attrition, the longitudinal sample used in the currently sample (inclusion criteria provided above) across the first two years of data collected for this set of analyses is approximately 400.
registration_responses.q14: Sample size predetermined by constraints on the longitudinal study.
registration_responses.q15: not relevant -- data already fully collected.
registration_responses.q20: Narrative variables are coded using coding systems available on the main IPP page for exploratory processing and self-event connections.
registration_responses.q21: We will use traditional p < .05 significance testing for our analyses.
registration_responses.q24: We have specific hypotheses and corresponding regression analyses spelled out above, but we simply plan to look at the bivariate correlations among all of main study variables in order to understand what is going on. This is a hugely labor intensive  long-term longitudinal study, and it makes sense to explore the data to build on it for future research.
registration_responses.q8.question: As mentioned above data are drawn from the Identity Pathways Project, which is documented on this OSF page.  The overall design is provided there.  There are three surveys a year each for four years of college, and the surveys include many quantitative scales and narrative prompts.  For the current analyses, mindset was measured at Wave 1 (summer before college) and Wave 4 (beginning of sophomore year), SES indicators were measured at Wave 1, academic high point and low point narratives were provided at Waves 3 (end of first year) and Wave 6 (end of sophomore year) and the academic adjustment measure was provided at Wave 2 (middle of first year) and Wave 5 (middle of sophomore year).  Finally, GPA was assessed at Wave 4 (beginning of sophomore year).
registration_responses.q12.question: See general materials for IPP for the data collection procedures for the longitudinal study.  For this specific set of analyses, we used a specific set of inclusion criteria regarding who from the longitudinal study would be included.  Our inclusion criteria was that we would include all those participants who a) completed Wave 1 (mindset  and SES) and Wave 4 (GPA), and b) completed at least one wave including one of the subjective academic outcome indicators, which would mean completing either Wave 2 (academic adjustment), Wave 3 (academic high points and low points for first year), Wave 5 (academic adjustment) or Wave 6 (academic high points and low points for sophomore year).
registration_responses.q16.question: No manipulated variables.
registration_responses.q17.question: See above, the variables are mindset (fixed vs. growth mindset for ability) at two time points -- Wave 1 and Wave 4; academic adjustment scale at Waves 2 and 5, positive and negative self-event connections and exploratory processing coded from academic high point and low point narratives at Waves 3 and 6; indicators of SES at Wave 1, and GPA at Wave 4.
registration_responses.q18.question: For SES, we are using a composite of household income, father's educational attainment, and mother's educational attainment.  These three variables will be z-scored and averaged together.
registration_responses.q19.question: Correlational and regression analyses will be used.  All bivariate correlations among study variables will be run. Specifically,  mindset scales will be correlated with SES indicators and indicators of academic adjustment, academic narrative identity, and GPA.  Additionally, multiple regression analysis will be used to examine how mindset predicts change in academic indicators over time, with and without controlling for GPA.  Finally, moderated multiple regression will be used to test whether SES moderates relations between mindset and academic outcomes.

attributes.title: Assessment of research integrity and quality in the use of antihypertensives for the management of preeclampsia

q1.value: Assessment of research integrity and quality in the use of antihypertensives for the management of preeclampsia

q3.value:
There is increasing awareness of issues with data integrity and quality in research, and many studies of poor quality and questionable data integrity are included in the systematic reviews and meta-analyses that inform clinical practice. Our research group has developed a tool to assess the integrity and quality of research in order to identify issues in research methodology and study execution. 
The purpose of this study is to validate the use of our data integrity assessment tool in the setting of choice of antihypertensives for the management of hypertension in preeclampsia.

q4.value:
STUDY AIMS
A) Assess study methodology with regards to registration, statistical analysis, and the probability of randomisation in RCT’s related to the use of antihypertensives in pregnancy with mild to moderate hypertension and severe hypertension respectively. 
B) Compare methodological issues based on publication year, single/multi-centre RCT and sample size. 
C) Compare our novel assessment of data integrity and methodological quality with the established GRADE approach. 

HYPOTHESES
A) Issues of methodology and data integrity are present in the randomised control trials examining choice of antihypertensives for the management of preeclampsia 
B) Our novel quality assessment tool will identify issues related to data integrity and methodology and provide additional information to that identified by the GRADE approach. 
C) Issues in methodology will be higher in older studies, studies of smaller sample size and multi-centre RCT's.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

q7.value:
Data extraction will be performed independently by two blinded reviewers with conflicts resolved by a third reviewer. 

Two independent blinded reviewers will perform the GRADE assessment, and conflicts will be resolved using a third reviewer.

question.value: This is a meta-epidemiological study. Further detail regarding study design is provided in the attached study protocol. This study will involve two phases. In phase 1, we will assess the randomised control trials (RCT) performed to examine the choice of antihypertensive in mild to moderate hypertension in pregnancy. These RCT's (n=29) will be identified using the Cochrane review published by Abalos et al (2018). In phase 2, we will assess RCT's examining the choice of antihypertensive for severe hypertension in pregnancy. These RCT's (n=69) will be identified through three meta-analysis by Duley et al (2013), Sridharan et al (2018), Alavifard et al (2019). Data will be extracted from these RCT's by two independent blinded reviewers with regards to author, year of publication, country/region, number and locations of study centres, number of participants, treatment, control, study start and end dates, registration (status and date), date of submission to journal, statement of ethics approval, sample size plan, statistical methods planned and used, reporting of drop outs, summary statistics of baseline characteristics, and univariable analyses. Quality of studies will be assessed through using the GRADE approach, assessment of trial registration, assessment of statistical analysis, assessment of ethics approval; feasibility of recruitment timeline; incidence of outcomes; variations between published data to registered protocol; poor reporting of drop outs and loss to follow up; and inconsistencies in the manuscript. Exploratory analyses will also be performed to assess contributing factors to study quality, with particular focus on sample size, publication year, and single VS multi site study recruitment. We will also perform a qualitative comparison between our novel quality assessment tool and the currently used GRADE approach.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
IDENTIFICATION OF PUBLISHED RANDOMISED CONTROL TRIALS FOR ANALYSIS:  
In Phase 1 we will include the RCT’s identified by the Cochrane review performed by Alabos et al (2018). Overall, this review identified 29 RCT’s examining antihypertensives in mild-moderate hypertension. In Phase 2, choice of antihypertensive for severe hypertension will be assessed by examining RCT's identified by 1) the Cochrane review by Duley et al (2013), 2) the network meta-analysis by Sridharan et al (2018), and 3) the network meta-analysis by Alavifard et al (2019). This will include a total of 69 RCT’s across all three systematic reviews and meta-anlayses. We have chosen to identify RCTs using these published reviews because these studies have been identified by an independent group that are not involved in our research project. As such, our assessment of data integrity will be less prone to selection bias. Furthermore, by including different meta-analysis which have demonstrated discrepant results we may then be able to determine whether data integrity and study quality explain the varied findings of these studies. 

DATA EXTRACTION:
We will extract information regarding author, year of publication, country/region, number and locations of study centres, number of participants, treatment, control, study start and end dates, registration (status and date), date of submission to journal, statement of ethics approval, sample size plan, statistical methods planned and used, reporting of drop outs, summary statistics of baseline characteristics, and univariable analyses. Any information appearing to not align with rigorous best practices in clinical trials will be recorded for further discussion. Data extraction will be performed independently by two blinded reviewers with conflicts resolved by a third reviewer.

q13.value:
Assessment of RCT's examining mild to moderate hypertension - 29 studies. 
Assessment of RCT's examining severe hypertension - 69 studies.

q15.value: This is a study assessing the quality and integrity of RCT's examining the choice of antihypertensive for management of hypertension in pregnancy. We will be assessing previously published RCT's that we have identified prior to data extraction.

question.value: Not applicable

1) ASSESSMENT OF STUDY QUALITY USING GRADE APPROACH: This will involve using the Risk of Bias Tool (RoB 2.0 Cochrane) for the primary outcome of progression to severe hypertension. 
2) ASSESSMENT OF TRIAL REGISTRATION: This will be performed for RCT's published after July 1 2005. Trial registration status will be categorised into one of four groups, registrations occurring 1) prior to commencing recruitment or within 6 months of initiating recruitment (adequate), 2) after 6 months of initiating recruitment but before the completion of recruitment (late), 3) trials registered after completing recruitment (retrospective) or 4) not registered at all (absent). Late, retrospective and absent registration will be considered as inadequate registration in the analysis. 
3) REPORTING OF STATISTICAL METHODS: This will be categorised into four categories - A) an absent or extremely brief description of the statistical method that hindered us from reproducing univariable analysis; B) inconsistency between the specified method and analyses presented in the results section (including tables and figures); C) use of statistical methods that were not pre-specified; D) inappropriate choice of statistical methods given the data type
4) ASSESSMENT OF SAMPLE SIZE CALCULATION: This will be categorised into the 3 categories of A) no sample size calculation; B) have sample size description but not possible to repeat; C) have sample size description and is possible to repeat.
5) REPRODUCIBILITY OF STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: We will report the inconsistency rate for each RCT by comparing our computed results with those published. Inconsistency rates will be compared using the Mann Whitney test.
6) PROBABILITY OF RANDOM SAMPLING OF BASELINE CHARACTERISTICS: This will be performed using Monte Carlo simulations and the Kolmogorov Smirnov test. For further details, please see the study protocol.
7) OTHER MISCELLANEOUS VARIABLES TO ASSESS QUALITY: This will include assessment of  
A) lack of statement confirming ethics approval, B) recruitment or study timelines that appear not to be feasible, C) distribution or incidence of outcomes, D) variation between published data to registration protocol, E) poor reporting of drop outs and loss to follow up, F) inconsistencies in the manuscript.
Not applicable

ASSESSMENT OF TRIAL REGISTRATION: 
Distribution of registration status will be compared using Fisher’s exact test.

REPORTING OF STATISTICAL METHODS: 
A composite of the issues in statistical methods (discussed in greater detail in the study protocol) will be compared using Fisher's exact test.

REPRODUCIBILITY OF STATISTICAL ANALYSIS: 
For the comparison of the means of continuous variables using an independent two sample t test and one way ANOVA, we will reproduce these analyses with corresponding mean, standard deviation, and the number of patients reported in the tables and texts. For the t test and one way ANOVA, inconsistency will be reported only when computed p values deviate from reported ones by more than 0.03. For the comparison of categorical variables that used the chi square test (with or without continuity correction) or Fisher’s exact test, we will reproduce the analysis with absolute numbers given in tables presenting the cross tabulation of categorical variables. Unadjusted odds ratios and risk ratios will also be calculated. We will report the inconsistency rate for each RCT by comparing our computed results with those published.

PROBABILITY OF RANDOM SAMPLING OF BASELINE CHARACTERISTICS:
This will be assessed using Monte Carlo simulations and the Kolmogorov Smirnov test. Please refer to study protocol for greater detail.

q21.value: We will use p-values to make statistical inferences. P<0.05 will be cut-off. All tests will be two-sided. As there are limited parallel tests, multiplicity will not be accounted for in this study.

q22.value: As this is a meta-epidemiological study, all data from eligible studies will be included. No statistical considerations will be given in regard to this question

q23.value: If missing or incomplete information is available, authors will be contacted regarding 1) trial registration information; and 2) miscellaneous issues related to lacking a statement confirming ethics approval, recruitment or study timelines that appear not to be feasible, distribution or incidence of outcomes, variation between published data to registration protocol, poor reporting of drop outs and loss to follow up, and inconsistencies in the manuscript.

q24.value:
We will perform sub group and exploratory analyses to examine for associations between data quality and integrity. The subgroups assessed will include 1) year of publication, 2) primary sites of recruitment, 3) single VS multi centre recruitment, 4) sample sizes recruited 

We will also perform a qualitative comparison between our research tool and the GRADE approach to quality assessment.

summary.value:
As part of a large registered replication report, we recently conducted an experimental study in which we asked a sample of over 5000 people to recall a previous spending experience. Specifically, a final sample of 5199 participants recruited on mTurk were randomly assigned to recall and describe a time they spent approximately $20 on themselves (personal spending condition) or someone else (prosocial spending condition). Afterward, participants were asked to report their current positive affect on the Positive Affect and Negative Affect Scale (PANAS; Watson, Clark & Tellegen, 1988), their current positive emotion on the Scale of Positive and Negative Emotion (SPANE; Diener et al., 2009), and positive emotion at the time of purchase on the SPANE. Well-being was computed as noted in this previous pre-registration: https://tinyurl.com/ProsocialSpendingRRR. Consistent with past research (e.g., Aknin et al., 2013) and our pre-registered predictions, we found that participants randomly assigned to recall a time they spent money on others were happier on all measures, but this effect was small. 

Because this data set represents the largest collection of personal and prosocial spending memories to date, we would like to probe the content of the spending memories for greater insight. In particular, we plan to examine (1) whether personal and prosocial spending memories differ along several predicted dimensions, and (2) whether prosocial spending exhibiting greater levels of certain constructs are associated with greater post-recall self-reported well-being.

Thus far, spending memories have been coded by Pennebaker et al.'s (2015) Linguistic Inquiry and Word Count program (LIWC). This program analyzes textual entries and codes them along various dimensions, such as word count, tense, emotion, and motives. In addition, the LIWC codes have been merged with an existing datafile indicating (a) participant's self-reported well-being, and (b) randomly assigned condition.

attributes.title: Narrating the Future Self:  Relations with SES and Campus Culture in a Longitudinal Study of College Student Development

q1.value: Narrating the Future Self:  Relations with SES and Campus Culture in a Longitudinal Study of College Student Development

q3.value: This study uses the Identity Pathways Project, a longitudinal study of college student development, to examine how socioeconomic status (SES) and campus culture relate to college students’ narrative construction of the future self. We propose that higher SES and liberal arts (LA) cultures promote greater identity exploration across a wider range of domains than lower SES and state university (SA) cultures, which promote a more concrete and practical focus on academics and career. Students from two campuses provided three narratives of how events shaped the future self (sophomore, junior and senior year), which were coded for identity exploration, self-clarity, and domains. First, we hypothesize that higher SES and LA students will exhibit more exploration and a higher correlation between exploration and self-clarity than lower SES and SU students. Second, we hypothesize that lower SES and SU students will show greater self-clarity in the domain of academics/career. Finally, exploratory analyses will examine changes in these associations from sophomore to junior year, along with patterns of stability and change in exploratory processing and self-clarity over time, overall and by campus.

q4.value:
First, we hypothesize that exploratory processing coded from future self-defining memories would be positively associated with higher SES and being a student on a liberal arts campus relative to a state university campus. Further, given that we know the two campuses differ on SES, we plan to use a multiple regression to test whether these effects, if found, are overlapping or independent.

Second, we hypothesize that the correlation between exploratory processing and self-clarity will be positive and stronger for those higher in SES and at a liberal arts college, with the idea that higher SES backgrounds and liberal arts culture promote exploration as a basis of clarifying identity more so than lower SES and state university backgrounds.

Third, we hypothesize that lower SES and state university students will show higher levels of self-clarity in their future self-defining memories specifically when those memories involves academics/career.  We expect that lower SES and state university students go into college with a more practical and narrow focus on career than higher SES and liberal arts students.

We will test these hypotheses separately in sophomore, junior, and senior years of college.

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The Identity Pathways Project is a longitudinal study (see this OSF page for more info) that includes 12 waves of data collection (three waves a year for four years of college. In terms of the variables to be used in the current analyses, SES was measured at Wave 1 (summer before college started) and the future self-defining memory narratives were collected in the Fall of sophomore, junior and senior years (Waves 4, 7, and 10).  These narratives were coded using adapted coding systems for exploratory processing (Pals, 2006), self-clarity, and self/identity domain.  The future self-defining memory prompt asked students to write about an event over the previous year that had shaped their understanding of their future self.

q10.value: Registration prior to analysis of the data

q11.value: Although the study has been going since 2013 (see IPP full description), the future self-defining memories were recently coded for this project and have never been analyzed in any way.

question.value: The sampling procedure for IPP is described elsewhere on this OSF page. For this set of analyses, we included participants who had provided a self-defining memory in sophomore, junior or senior year (approx. 400 participants).  For the stability and change analyses, only those who provided a memory at all three time points were included.

q13.value: For these analyses, 334-396 participants were included in the analyses that related SES and campus to the narrative variables at sophomore, junior, and senior year separately.  For the stability and change analyses, the N was 254 (participants who had a memory at all three years).

q14.value: The IPP sample was determined by resources available and feasibility of implementation.

question.value: SES (Wave 1) composite of household income and parental education level; narrative variables coded from future self-defining memories -- exploratory processing, self-clarity and identity domains at waves 4, 7, and 10 (sophomore, junior, and senior year).
SES is calculated by z-scoring household income, mother's education and father's education and averaging them together.

1) Bivariate correlations between SES and the narrative variables (separately for Waves 4, 7, and 10)

registration_responses.q1: Narrating the Future Self:  Relations with SES and Campus Culture in a Longitudinal Study of College Student Development
registration_responses.q3: This study uses the Identity Pathways Project, a longitudinal study of college student development, to examine how socioeconomic status (SES) and campus culture relate to college students’ narrative construction of the future self. We propose that higher SES and liberal arts (LA) cultures promote greater identity exploration across a wider range of domains than lower SES and state university (SA) cultures, which promote a more concrete and practical focus on academics and career. Students from two campuses provided three narratives of how events shaped the future self (sophomore, junior and senior year), which were coded for identity exploration, self-clarity, and domains. First, we hypothesize that higher SES and LA students will exhibit more exploration and a higher correlation between exploration and self-clarity than lower SES and SU students. Second, we hypothesize that lower SES and SU students will show greater self-clarity in the domain of academics/career. Finally, exploratory analyses will examine changes in these associations from sophomore to junior year, along with patterns of stability and change in exploratory processing and self-clarity over time, overall and by campus.
registration_responses.q4:
First, we hypothesize that exploratory processing coded from future self-defining memories would be positively associated with higher SES and being a student on a liberal arts campus relative to a state university campus. Further, given that we know the two campuses differ on SES, we plan to use a multiple regression to test whether these effects, if found, are overlapping or independent.

Second, we hypothesize that the correlation between exploratory processing and self-clarity will be positive and stronger for those higher in SES and at a liberal arts college, with the idea that higher SES backgrounds and liberal arts culture promote exploration as a basis of clarifying identity more so than lower SES and state university backgrounds.

Third, we hypothesize that lower SES and state university students will show higher levels of self-clarity in their future self-defining memories specifically when those memories involves academics/career.  We expect that lower SES and state university students go into college with a more practical and narrow focus on career than higher SES and liberal arts students.

We will test these hypotheses separately in sophomore, junior, and senior years of college.

q2.value: Kevin Aslett, Zeve Sanderson, Joshua A. Tucker, Jonathan Nagler, Richard Bonneau, William Godel, Nate Persily

q3.value:
This individual study is a part of a larger study that is motivated by two very closely related research questions.

First, recent literature on fake news identifies some types of individuals most likely to spread fake news across social media platforms. However, previous research has much less to say about who possesses the ability to discern fake from genuine news and, therefore, who is most vulnerable to believing fake news to be true, or, conversely, believing true news to be false.

While we seek to test these hypotheses in order to advance scientific understanding of the determinants of susceptibility to believing fake news to be true (or true news to be false), we are also motivated by two pragmatic questions. First, is it possible to "crowd-source" fact checking in a way that allows us to come reasonably close to matching the performance of professional fact checkers?  Second, what is the trade-off between making our crowd representative of the general population -- which may be desirable for normative or political reasons -- and the average level of the crowd's accuracy?  In answering this second question, we draw upon the empirical findings from our first set of individual-level hypotheses that are laid out in a previous pre-registration (https://osf.io/dp8ze/?view_only=4c3c24c0cb9f4625ba2574c7bd5aac9f). In this study we will test a series of hypotheses about individual-level characteristics and article evaluation task-flows associated with correctly discerning fake news from true news. We will introduce an intervention that asks respondents to evaluate articles given in three distinct forms: (1) just the headline and lede of the article in standardized text format, (2) A screenshot of just the headline and lede of the article taken directly from the website, (3) the full text of an article in standardized text format. We will also use these results to help us evaluate what might impact the trade off between representative and accuracy of the crowd if this intervention were introduced.

In the current study, we plan to run a ten day survey in which individuals evaluate fake and true news stories within 24 hours of their publication online. For the purpose of this study, we will ascertain whether each article is true, false/misleading, or whether the veracity of the story is unclear by having a team of professional fact-checkers label the story along these lines. Respondents in our survey will be required to complete the survey within 24 hours of when the survey is open for responses. Therefore, respondents will evaluate these articles within the first 48 hours after they are published online. The survey will be run for ten days (due to difficulties with recruitment on Fridays, the survey will only be open on Mondays, Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays). The survey will start on a Wednesday.

Each day a new group of 5 articles will be selected for evaluation. These articles will be sent to be evaluated by 150 unique respondents in all four groups (600 respondents total). Each respondent will be randomly given three of the five articles to evaluate in a randomized order. Over the course of two and a half weeks (the survey will be sent out on ten days throughout this period) we will recruit 600 unique individuals per day to take our survey. The control group (150 respondents per day) is asked to evaluate articles for veracity and is given the whole article to evaluate on their website. The 1st treatment group (150 respondents per day) is given the whole article in standardized text to evaluate. The 2nd treatment group (150 respondents per day) is given the headline and lede of the article in standardized text to evaluate. The 3rd treatment group (150 respondents per day) is given the headline and lede of the article as a screenshot from its website to evaluate.

To track the information individuals engage with if they choose to search for evidence to evaluate the news article, we run google searches using the headline of the article hourly and scrape the top eleven search results during the 24-hour period in which the survey is open. We collect the URL, headline shown in each google search result, text below the headline shown in each google search result, and the full text from each article that is in the top eleven search results.

As explained in much greater detail below, we will test how the intervention of only evaluating the headline and lede or only viewing the text in a standardized format has different effects on how individuals are able to identify fake news and true news.

q4.value:
1. The  first  set  of  hypotheses  pose  the  question  of  how  more  text  from  an  article  effects  how  respondents evaluate the veracity of an article.  We believe that if respondents are given more information respondents are more likely to match fact-checkers.

(1.a)  Respondents who are only given the headline and lede in standardized text of an article to evaluate are less likely to match the assessment of fact-checkers than those who are given the whole article in standardized text to evaluate.  We believe that more text helps respondents evaluate articles, but  this  may  depend  on  the  complexity  of  text.   If  an  article  is  more  difficult  to  comprehend,more text may actually obscure respondents from matching fact-checkers.  To be clear, this is not a hypothesis we are positing here, but it is something we plan to explore after the experiment.

(1.b)  Respondents  who  are  only  given  the  headline  and  lede  of  an  article  to  evaluate  (with  source information) are less likely to match the assessment of fact-checkers than those who are given the whole article to evaluate (with source information).  We believe that more text helps respondents evaluate articles, but this may depend on the complexity of text.  If an article is more difficult to comprehend, more text may actually obscure respondents from matching fact-checkers.  To be clear, this is not a hypothesis we are positing here, but it is something we plan to explore after the experiment.

2.  The second set of hypotheses pose the question of how more information about the source of the article impacts how respondents rate the veracity of articles.  This applies to respondents who are given the full  text  and  the  headline  and  lede  of  the  article  to  evaluate.   We  believe  that  being  given  source information from a mainstream news article and a fake news source has different effects.  Being given information that the article is from a mainstream source increases the likelihood a respondent believes it is true.  Whereas, being given information that the article is from a source known for publishing fake news increases the likelihood a respondent believes it is misleading/false.

(2.a)  Respondents who evaluate the full standardized text from articles known for publishing fake news will be more likely to rate this story as true than respondents who evaluate the full article from their website (with the source information).

(2.b)  Respondents who evaluate the full standardized text of an mainstream news article will be less likely to rate this story as true than respondents who evaluate the full article from their website(with the source information).

(2.c)  Respondents who evaluate the headline and lede in standardized text from an article known for publishing fake news will be more likely to rate this story as true than respondents who evaluate the headline and lede from their website (with the source information).

(2.d)  Respondents who evaluate the headline and lede in standardized text from an mainstream news article will be less likely to rate this story as true than respondents who evaluate the headline and lede from their website (with the source information).

3.  The third set of hypotheses pose the question of how more information about the source of an article impacts how respondents evaluate articles that are congruent or incongruent to their political ideology.Individuals are more likely to believe a source if it is congruent to their political ideology.  They are less likely if it is incongruent.

(3.a)  When evaluating the whole text of an article from a source congruent to their political ideology,respondents are more likely to rate a story as true when evaluating the article from its website(given source information) than when given in standardized text (without source information).

(3.b)  When evaluating the whole text of an article from a source incongruent to their political ideology,respondents  are  less  likely  to  rate  a  story  as  true  when  evaluating  the  article  from  its  website(given source information) than when given in standardized text (without source information).

(3.c)  When  evaluating  the  headline  and  lede  of  an  article  from  a  source  congruent  to  their  political ideology,  respondents are more likely to rate a story as true when evaluating the headline and lede from its website (given source information) than when given in standardized text (without source information).

(3.d)  When evaluating the headline and lede of an article from a source incongruent to their political ideology, respondents are less likely to rate a story as true when evaluating the headline and lede from its website (given source information) than when given in standardized text (without source information).

The survey firm Qualtrics will recruit and administer the survey online. Each group of respondents (the control and treatment groups) is balanced by partisanship (we use census proportions which approximate to: 1/3 who self-identify as democrat, 1/3 who self-identify as moderate, 1/3 who identify as republican), gender (we use census proportions which approximate to: 1/2 who self-identify as male ; 1/2 who self-identify as female), age (we use census proportions which approximate to: 18-34: 1/3 ; 35-54: 1/3; 55 and above: 1/3) and education (1/2 have no high school/ high school degree/partial college; 1/2 have a college degree or more). Only articles within 24 hours of publication from fake news websites (3 of the 5 articles) and mainstream websites (2 of the 5 articles) are sent to these respondents. The three fake news articles come from three different locations: One news story comes from a liberal-leaning news site that has been identified as publishing fake news in the past, one news story comes from a conservative-leaning news site that has been identified as publishing fake news in the past, one news story comes from a news site with no clear political orientation that has been identified as publishing fake news in the past. The two mainstream news articles come from two different locations: One news story comes from a liberal-leaning news site that has been identified as a mainstream news site and one news story comes from a conservative-leaning news site that has been identified as a mainstream news site. Each respondent in the control group evaluates three of the five articles (chosen at random and given in random order). Each respondent in the treatment group evaluates all five articles (given in random order). These articles are simultaneously evaluated by professional fact-checkers. The scores of respondents and professional fact-checkers will be compared to determine if respondents correctly evaluated news articles. Survey respondents must answer every question on the survey.

question.value: Human subjects are recruited by Qualtrics. This survey firm recruits individuals through various means. They are paid for their participation in either airline miles or direct transfers of money. Not all respondents are paid the same amount as it is up to both the participant and the vendor (Qualtrics) to negotiate terms. The handling of this by Qualtrics maintains the anonymity of the respondents in our survey. Survey respondents must answer every question on the survey.

q13.value: Each day we recruit 600 unique individuals (150 individuals for the control group and 150 individuals for each treatment group) through Qualtrics (the survey runs for ten days). Each group of human subjects is balanced every day by partisanship (We use census proportions which approximate to: 1/3 who self-identify as a democrat, 1/3 who self-identify as moderate, 1/3 who identify as republican), gender (We use census proportions which approximate to: 1/2 who self-identify as male ; 1/2 who self-identify as female), and education (1/2 have no high school/ high school degree/partial college; 1/2 have a college degree or more). They are paid for their participation in either airline miles or direct transfers of money. Not all respondents are paid the same amount as it is up to the vendor (Qualtrics). In total we should have 6,000 unique respondents (1,500 unique respondents in the control group and 4,500 unique respondents in the treatment group) balanced on the demographics just outlined. Therefore in the control group we should receive 4,500 evaluations of 50 articles (90 per article). In each treatment group we should also receive 4,500 evaluations of 50 articles (90 per article).

attributes.title: Memory for Eating at Different Rates

q1.value: Eating Fast and Slow: Memory for eating at different eating rates.

q3.value: Memory of recent eating appears to play a role in moderating future food consumption such that stronger recent meal memories lead to reduced future eating. Thus, there is merit in identifying determinants of meal memories. One possible determinant is eating pace, particularly because more distributed encoding of information has long been known to enhance recall. Only a small number of studies have tested how eating rate affects memory of eating and these studies are severely underpowered and some rely on eating conditions that lack external validity. We therefore will test how fast vs slow eating affects memory of eating using the Memory of Eating Task (MEaT) [https://osf.io/ejtu6/] we have developed for other memory of eating studies and a large number of participants (n = 128).

q4.value: We predict participants in the slow eating condition will more accurately recall how much food they consumed compared to participants in the fast eating condition. Thus, this is a directional hypothesis, with memory for eating being more accurate in slow > fast eaters.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This is a simple between subjects experimental design. Participants will be assigned to either eat 30 M&Ms on average every 45 seconds (slow condition) or 30 M&Ms on average every 15 seconds (fast condition) over the course of a 22.5 minute video. The fast eating condition will begin eating 15 minutes into the video.

q9.value: Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two equally sized, predetermined blocks.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through UCLA's SONA system, and all participants will be UCLA undergraduates 18+. The study description will warn all participants not to participate in this experiment if they have any type of food allergy and to refrain from eating 2 hours prior to completing the study. All participants who do not comply with this will not be allowed to participate. Participants will be compensated with course credit.

q13.value: 128 human subjects will be recruited to participate in this study.

q14.value: Sample size was determined by G*power to detect a medium effect size (d=0.5) with 80% power.

question.value: We manipulated the pace of eating 30 M&Ms in this procedure. Participants either ate the M&Ms fast (every 15s) or slow (every 45s).

We are primarily interested in memory accuracy for how many items of food were consumed. Participants will be asked how many pieces of their respective item they consumed during the task. 

Participants will also recreate the task environment using a Microsoft Powerpoint template. This will be scored by 2 independent reviewers.
We will conduct a one-tailed t test between memory for slow eating vs memory for fast eating. We predict memory for slow eating will be more accurate than memory for fast eating.
